summary: An email from an Assistant United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York to FBI and NYPD contacts regarding follow-up tasks in the Ghislaine Maxwell case. The tasks include reviewing interview reports, locating evidence, and identifying Palm Beach Police Department witnesses to authenticate items seized from Jeffrey Epstein's residence.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the email and the case for which tasks are being coordinated.

persons.name: Assistant United States Attorney Southern District of New York
persons.context: The sender of the email, coordinating investigative tasks related to the Maxwell case.

connections.person1: Assistant United States Attorney Southern District of New York
connections.description: The AUSA is coordinating the investigation and prosecution of Maxwell.

events.title: Interview of witness
events.description: An interview was conducted with a witness (name redacted) as part of the Maxwell investigation.

events.title: Interview of witness
events.description: A second interview was conducted with a witness (name redacted) as part of the Maxwell investigation.

events.title: Seizure of evidence from Epstein's Palm Beach residence
events.description: Items including message pads were seized from Jeffrey Epstein's Palm Beach residence by the Palm Beach Police Department.

keyFacts: Prosecutors were actively working on the Ghislaine Maxwell case as of February 2021, coordinating with FBI and NYPD.
Interviews of at least one witness were conducted on January 20 and 21, 2021, with draft FBI 302 reports needing review.
Investigators sought to authenticate specific evidence, including message pads, seized from Jeffrey Epstein's Palm Beach residence.
The email references the Capitol investigation impacting CART (Computer Analysis and Response Team) resources, indicating competing priorities.
The prosecutor provided a ranked list of potential PBPD witnesses, including an Evidence Specialist, a CSI photographer, and a Detective, based on their roles in the evidence seizure.
